results.title: Are you positive?
results.creator_credit: Eric Porter, Ed Cullen and Artransa Park Studios
results.brief_description: Describes and refutes various common misconceptions about tuberculosis. Shows how erroneous beliefs have arisen and analysis of the mistaken ideas that tuberculosis is no longer a serious disease; that it is easy to control with drugs; that long periods in hospital are not necessary; that it does not affect old people; that people who feel fit cannot be infected. The simple precautions of chest X-ray and skin tests are explained.

results.title: Are you listening?
results.brief_description: Observes the operation of the Development Music Programme, adapted by Deanna Hoermann form the Kodaly method, in New South Wales, where children are being trained to be musically literate. Results show improvements in mathematics, reading, memory, concentration and other learning skills.Classroom activities in kindergarten and primary grades show the techniques and concepts used. Suitable for Upper Secondary and Tertiary students.

results.title: Are we really doing well?
results.brief_description: Examines the services provided by the management consultant company Inter-Firm Comparison Service and their different approaches to helping small business proprietors in the areas of efficiency, profitability, flexibility and industrial and public relations. No other credits available.

results.title: Are we doing enough about retirement?
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “BBC 24 Hours”.
To many people retirement comes as a shock and leaves a vacuum in their lives which is all too often filled with worries about their health. An association in Birmingham which tries to help people enjoy their retired years, and a workshop where people work half time shifts in an attempt to improve the situation. No other credits available.

results.title: Are people sheep?
results.creator_credit: Julian Biggs, Grant McLean and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Discusses social conformity, citing everyday incidents as examples of obedience to custom in present day society - the little boy who felt his birthday gift would not be liked because it was different; the housewife who flew into a frenzy of tidying up when the door-bell rang; the teenage daughter who believed she must adopt behaviour beyond her years in order to be accepted. The film concludes with an interview with Dr Brock Chisholm, psychiatrist and former head of the World Health Organization, who comments on the importance to our society of the visionary who looks beyond the confines of convention.

results.title: Arctic outpost
results.creator_credit: John Feeney, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Life at the small settlement of Pangnirtung on eastern Baffin Island, where there is as a Royal Canadian Mounted Police post, a Hudson’s Bay Company store, a mission hospital and a government school. The film presents on-the-spot accounts of the work of all of these. This is a shorter version of the film “Pangnirtung”.

results.title: Arctic nomads
results.brief_description: Life at the tiny outpost of Masi, on the edge of the vast Finnmark plateau over which the nomadic Lapps have wandered for centuries. Lapp children are shown at their lessons in a school built be the Norwegian State. Out on the plateau a family is shown living a primitive tent life, and preparing their sledges and reindeer to migrate to the coast in the spring. No other credits available.

results.title: Arctic jungle
results.creator_credit: Sydney Newman and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Canada carries on”.
The life of the Eskimo is a constant struggle for existence against the harshness of the Arctic environment. The film shows spear fishing, making lamp fuel, manufacturing clothing and kayaks, and hunting powerful quarry like the polar bear and white whale.

results.title: Arctic dog team
results.brief_description: A study of the training of husky dogs for their work in the Arctic and of the valuable part they play in the life of the Eskimos. Commentary by Doug Wilkinson. No other credits available.

results.title: Arctic 4
results.creator_credit: Colin Low and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A long film report of a new and daring step toward understanding what lies under the Arctic ice. This is the story of an Arctic diving expedition led by Dr. Joseph MacInnes and a team of scientists, during two months of continuous springtime daylight. The dives are a test of both men and equipment as well as an exploration of the high northern marine environment. What they discovered is interestingly documented in this film.
